oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An Open Letter To The Knox County Election Commission. Gentlemen: It has been announced that your commission has instructed registrars to compel women to give their exact age when applying for a registration certificate. It is the purpose of this communication to ask you to give your reason to the public for giving such instruction. It is most probable that many are as much puzzled as I am, as to the necessity or advisability of such an interpretation of the election law. I hope that it is not due to mental weakness that I cannot think of one single reason why registrars should know the exact age of any one who applies for a certificate to vote. The registrar must have reason to believe that the applicant has arrived at the legal age, twenty-one, which is required by our state law of every voter. Why should the registrar know anything more as regards the age of applicants? One of the commission is reported as saying, "The women now have got into politics and they must be reconciled to complying with all requirements." If the requirement is one which in no way promotes the interest of the public but is most displeasing to many electors, why should they obey it? I have not the election law to which to refer, but I venture to say it is not the intent of that law to pry into the private personal affairs of electors. Every elector should resist, by endeavoring to have changed, any law which approaches tyranny even though it involves so small a matter as the exact age of the voter. You are not compelled to put a tyrannical construction on this law, why do so? MRS. L. C. FRENCH.
